The Cabinet resumed the discussion begunat the previous Meeting on the subject of Poor law reform and Block Grants.The Cabinet were informed that the request for a decision asked for at the previous Meeting asthe result of the conference between the Chancellorof the Exchequer, the Minister of Health and thePresident of the Board of Education, had been madeon the assumption that there would be no further meeting of the Cabinet before February next. Asthe Cabinet is likely to meet in the latter half ofJanuary, the Ministers concerned were quite preparedto modify their previous request.In the circumstances, after a full discussionof the whole question, the Cabinet agreed (a) That the Minister of Health should press on with the preparation of aBill to give effect to his proposals in regard to Poor Law Reform, on thelines proposed at the previous Meet-ing, as well as with the letter tothe Local Authorities explaining thatthe financial provisions were not included in the Bill as the Governmenthad resolved to investigate a largerscheme which would embrace education and Police as well as Health, and stating explicitly that,if theseproposals were proceeded with, noLocal Authority should be worse offfinancially than at present:(b) That the Minister of Health should include in the first draft of his BillClauses for the purpose of deprivingpersons who had been in receipt of poor Relief since the last election of the exercise of the Municipalfranchise:(a) That Sir George Barstow's Inter-Departmental Committee should con-tinue its investigation on the qn.es-tion of Block Grants in greater detail under instructions to be drawnup by the Chancellor of the exchequer in consultation with the other ministers concerned:(d) ^hat the Minister of Agriculture andFisheries should have the right to nominate a representative to attend Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1.December 17, 1926.the meetings of Sir George Barstow'sCommittee:(e) That the Minister of Health'e bill and the covering letter, togetherwith a further Report fromSir George BarstoWs Committee,Should be considered by the Cabinetin the latter half of January, andthat the Minister of Health should postpone tha circulation of theBill and the accompanying letterto the Local Authorities until after the Cabinet had consideredthe matter:(f) To take note that a correspondingBill, mutatis mutandis, would berequired for Scotland.
